question: I had a cardiac CT scan last week b/c of family history and some very minor pains that i couldn't determine if or not were chest related.  I was hoping to have the test and get a negative reading and move on.  My father passed away at 61 from heart disease and had hbp since his early 20's.  My results were not was I was hoping for.  My calcium score was 43.70.  I am a 42 yr old female 5'2" /140pds that eats right and exercises regularly.  I feel like I have been handed a death sentence and am very concerned.  I realize that the score may not sound that high to some but it puts me in the 91% for my age group.  I followed up with a cardiologist and she said it was a red flag at my age, and that I should be at 0.  She ordered two blood tests that break down my cholesterol and look at how big the particles are in the LDL and said she after reviewing those she may either prescribe a statin or niacin.  I should also add that my trig's, and all cholesterol numbers are within normal range and I do not smoke or have diabetes.  I have a 2yrd old daughter who is the love of my life and did develop pregnancy induced hypertension after her delivery.  I have been on bp meds since that time and my bp is well under control -normally averages 115/70.  My husband thinks I am overreacting, and pretty much ignores me at this point.  I was reading the ask a doctor forum a few days ago and one of the doctors suggested viewing the "trackyourplaque.com" site.  I downloaded a book that goes into great detail about cardiac ct's, and it made me even more alarmed.  it said in chapter 3 i believe that with my age & score my chances of a cardiac related event are around 10% and that if nothing is done that I can count on my score going up 30% per year.  That scares me to death b/c I have already been practicing a heart healthy lifestyle for several years.  I will do anything it takes to be able to raise my beautiful daughter and be there to see her graduate from high school and walk down the aisle.  Any ideas?  Please help.
title: cardiac calcium score
